Text:
Design B-65 cruiser

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to: navigation, search
Design B-65.svg
A line drawing of the proposed Design B-65.
Class overview
Name: Design B-65
Operators: Empire of Japan Imperial Japanese Navy
Planned: 2
Completed: 0
General characteristics
Type: Super Type A cruiser
Displacement: Standard: 31,905 t (31,401 long tons)[1]
Full-load: 35,000 t (34,000 long tons)
Length: 240 m (790 ft) length at the waterline[1]
246.2 m (808 ft) length overall[1]
Beam: 27.2 m (89 ft)[1]
Draft: 8.8 m (29 ft) (trial)[1]
Propulsion: Four sets of geared turbines and eight Kampon boilers would yield 170,000 metric horsepower (167,674 shaft horsepower); this would have been able to drive the ship at 33 kn (38 mph; 61 km/h)[2]
Endurance: 8,000 mi (13,000 km) at 18 kn (21 mph; 33 km/h)[1]
Armament: 9 × 310 mm (12.2 in)/50 caliber guns (3 × 3)[1]
16 × 100 mm (3.9 in)/65 caliber dual-purpose guns (8 × 2)[1]
12 × 25 mm (0.98 in) anti-aircraft guns (6 × 2)[1]
4 × 13 mm (0.51 in) machine guns (2 × 2)[1]
8 × 610 mm (24 in) torpedo tubes (4 × 2)[1]
Armor: 210 mm (8.3 in) to 190 mm (7.5 in) barbettes 190 mm (7.5 in) side armor inclined 20 degrees
125 mm (5 in) armored deck 180 mm (7.1 in) conning tower sides 125 mm (4.9 in) conning tower roof [3]

Design B-65 was a class of Super Type A cruisers[A 1] planned by the Imperial Japanese Navy (IJN) before and during World War II. As envisioned by the IJN, the cruisers were to play a key role in the Night Battle Force portion of the "Decisive battle" strategy which Japan hoped, in the event of war, to employ against the United States Navy.

Begun in 1939, plans were far enough along that tests were conducted with the main armament and against the underwater protection. Even though the ships were approved for construction under a 1942 fleet replenishment program, the prioritizing of aircraft carriers and smaller ships due to the war, followed by Japan's defeat, killed any chance of the B-65's construction.

Mission and plan[edit]

The Japanese navy's experience in the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-1905, especially the Battle of Tsushima, strongly influenced the creation of the IJN's "Decisive Battle" doctrine, which guided the development and deployment of the IJN's battle fleet into World War II. The Decisive Battle concept was the IJN's primary strategy for defeating the navies of the major Western powers, such as Great Britain or the United States, in the event of war. The strategy consisted of four main components: a decisive surface fleet engagement determined by big guns, attrition tactics against a numerically superior enemy, a reliance on quality over quantity in naval weaponry, and the employment of nighttime torpedo attacks.[4]

After the Washington Naval Treaty of 1922 and the London Naval Treaty of 1930, each of which placed restrictions on the size of the IJN's fleet in comparison with the fleets of the western powers, notably the United States, the decisive battle strategy received increased emphasis within the IJN. In 1936, the IJN formed the Night Battle Force (Yasen Butai). As designed, the night battle force was to attack the hypothetical enemy's, usually envisioned by the Japanese to be the US Pacific Fleet, outer defense ring of cruisers and destroyers at night. After cracking the outer defense ring, IJN cruisers and destroyers were to launch torpedo attacks on the enemy's battleships. What remained of the enemy fleet was then to be finished-off by the IJN's main battleship line the following day.[5]

The IJN assigned one division of fast battleships or battlecruisers to give additional firepower to the nocturnal attacks. The Kongō-class battlecruisers were initially assigned to this role and were upgraded to fast battleships over a seven-year period from 1933-1940. The IJN planned to eventually replace the four Kongō battleships with four heavy, "super" cruisers. As envisioned by the IJN in 1936, these ships, the B-65 cruisers, would mount 12-inch guns, carry armor designed to withstand hits from 8-inch shells, and be capable of speeds up to 40 knots. They would be designated as "super-A-class cruisers" to signify their greater status than the A-class ships (heavy cruisers).[1][6][7]

The plan for the cruiser class was finalized as part of the IJN's Circle Five and Circle Six warship construction plans of 7 January 1941. The plan called for six B-65s to be built in two increments, with the first two to be constructed in Circle 5 with the remainder in Circle 6.[8] By this time, Japanese intelligence had learned the specifications for the United States Navy's Alaska-class large cruisers,[9] which had been authorized for creation by the passage of the Two-Ocean Navy Act and ordered on 5 September 1940.[8][10] The Japanese believed that these ships would form part of the American battle fleet's screen in times of war. Thus, the B-65s were now intended to counter the threat posed by the Alaska-class cruisers.[8][11]


Design work on the B-65s began in 1939.[12] Preliminary plans for the new class were finished by September 1940, and they were far enough along that tests of the lower protection—the armor intended to counter any shell that fell short but still hit the ship (albeit underwater) and torpedoes—and main armament were conducted from 1940 to 1941.[1]

Yamato on her trials in 1941. Had they been built, the Design B-65 ships would have borne a striking resemblance to this ship.

These plans called for ships that bore a striking resemblance to the Yamato-class battleships, with the same "clipper bow, flush-deck construction, and a generally similar superstructure", albeit at a reduced size. Nine 310 mm (12.2 in)/50 caliber guns in three triple turrets, sixteen 100 mm (3.9 in)/65 caliber dual-purpose guns in dual mounts on either side of the superstructure, twelve paired 25 mm (0.98 in) anti-aircraft guns, four 13 mm (0.51 in) machine guns, and eight 610 mm (24 in) torpedo tubes were to be the primary weapons of the cruiser.[1][13] The weight of the main battery turrets was to be around 1,000 long tons (1,100 short tons; 1,000 t), with 350 long tons (390 short tons; 360 t) of that devoted to armor; however, no plans of how this latter figure was to have been distributed has survived.[14]

The cruisers were to be protected by 190 mm (7.5 in) belt armor sloped at 20° and 125 mm (4.9 in) deck armor.[1] Four geared turbine sets would have generated about 42,500 shp each;[8] for a total of about 167,674 shp,[8][15] enough to power the ships through the water at 34 kn (39 mph; 63 km/h),[1] faster than the "fundamental design requirement" of 33 kn (38 mph; 61 km/h).[15]

In an attempt to counter the Alaska-class cruisers '​ 305 mm (12.0 in) guns, a proposal to increase both the main battery to six 356 mm (14 in) and armor protection to resist against the same was put forth. However, the increase in displacement (to almost 40,000 long tons (45,000 short tons; 41,000 t)) and reduction in performance this entailed meant that nothing came of the proposed changes.[9][14][A 2]

Final plans and cancellation[edit]

As war with the United States loomed in 1941, the navy found that it had a more pressing need for aircraft carriers and auxiliary vessels. This need, plus a desire to complete the ongoing Circle Three and Four construction programs, delayed initiation of the Circle Five plan.[16]

Following the Japanese navy's defeat at the Battle of Midway in June 1942, the Circle Five plan was significantly revised and Circle Six was postponed indefinitely. The new plan still called for the construction of two ships of Design B-65, which were given the hull numbers 795 and 796 with projected commissioning dates of 1945 and 1946, respectively. As the war progressed, however, strategic requirements further delayed the plans for the two cruisers. In the end, the B-65s' plans were never finalized and no contracts for their construction were ever placed.[17][18][19]

See also[edit]


  1. ^ According to Conway's All the World's Fighting Ships 1922–1946, p. 178, the Japanese classified Super Type A cruisers as heavy cruisers; however, Garzke and Dulin assert in Battleships: Axis and Neutral Battleships in World War II, p. 86, that B-65 cruisers "would have satisfied every basic characteristic of the battlecruiser type."
  2. ^ Ironically, the Alaska-class cruisers were originally designed and ordered by the United States Navy because of mistaken intelligence reports stating that Japan was constructing "super cruisers" that would be much more powerful than the 8 in (203.2 mm)-gunned heavy cruisers the U.S. possessed. See: Gardiner and Chesneau, p. 122 and Pike, John (2008). "CB-1 Alaska Class". Retrieved 19 October 2008. 


  1. ^ a b c d e f g h i j k l m n o p Garzke and Dulin (1985), p. 86
  2. ^ Lacroix and Wells II, p. 830
  3. ^ Lacroix and Wells II, p. 606
  4. ^ Evans and Peattie, pp. 129–130
  5. ^ Evans and Peattie, pp. 273-276.
  6. ^ Evans and Peattie, pp. 275-277, 294; Lacroix and Wells II, pp. 250, 606.
  7. ^ Perfect Guide to Japanese Battleships, p. 140
  8. ^ a b c d e Lacroix and Wells II (1997), p. 606
  9. ^ a b Garzke and Dulin (1985), pp. 86–87
  10. ^ Pike, John (2008). "CB-1 Alaska Class". Retrieved 19 October 2008. 
  11. ^ Evans and Peattie, pp. 359-360.
  12. ^ Gardiner and Chesneau (1984), p. 178
  13. ^ DiGuilian, Tony (26 August 2007). "Japanese 10 cm/65 (3.9") Type 98". Navweaps. Retrieved 13 March 2009. 
  14. ^ a b Perfect Guide, p. 141
  15. ^ a b Garzke and Dulin (1985), p. 87
  16. ^ Evans and Peattie, p 360.
  17. ^ Garzke and Dulin (1985), p. 84–85
  18. ^ Lacroix and Wells II, p. 829.
  19. ^ Jentschura, p. 40.
response:
### **Design B-65 Cruiser Shipyard: A Multi-Agent Naval Construction Facility**  

#### **1. Overall Scene Theme and Core Concept**  
A sprawling **Imperial Japanese Navy shipyard** in the late 1930s, where the **unfinished Design B-65 "Super Type A" cruiser** sits partially assembled in Dry Dock No. 3. The scene is a **high-stakes industrial environment**—steel beams loom overhead, half-welded armor plates lie scattered, and a mix of naval engineers, welders, and laborers scramble to meet tight deadlines.  

**Why it's suited for multi-agent collaboration:**  
- **Heavy, oversized components** (gun turrets, armor plates, boilers) require coordinated lifting.  
- **Precision tool-use** (welding, riveting, calibration) demands specialized roles.  
- **Logistical complexity** (supply chains, inspections, emergency repairs) necessitates teamwork.  

---  

#### **2. Spatial Layout and Area Descriptions**  
The facility is divided into **five key zones**, each with distinct challenges:  

1. **Dry Dock No. 3 (Primary Workspace)** – The **B-65’s hull skeleton**, partially armored, with exposed bulkheads and a flooded basin below.  
2. **Machine Shop & Armory** – Where **gun turrets, torpedo tubes, and propulsion parts** are pre-assembled.  
3. **Material Storage Yard** – Stacked **steel plates, rivet crates, and heavy machinery** awaiting transport.  
4. **Design Office & Blueprint Room** – A cluttered space with **ship schematics, slide rules, and radio equipment**.  
5. **Boiler Testing Platform** – A high-pressure area where **steam turbines** undergo calibration.  

---  

### **3. Detailed Area-by-Area Inventory**  

#### **DRY DOCK NO. 3** *(Primary Assembly Zone)*  

**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Gantry Crane System** (10-ton capacity, steel cables frayed in spots).  
- **Partially Welded Hull Frame** (exposed ribbing, missing deck plating aft).  
- **Flooded Dry Dock Basin** (greenish water, oil sheen, floating debris).  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **310mm Gun Turret (Unmounted)** – 22-ton steel monstrosity on a reinforced dolly, **hydraulic lift pins misaligned**.  
- **Armor Plate Stack** – 190mm-thick sloped steel (each 3m x 4m, **requires two agents to maneuver**).  
- **Torpedo Tube Casing** – 610mm diameter, **half-bolted to the hull, missing fasteners**.  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Rivet Furnace** (coal-fired, glowing embers, tongs nearby).  
- **Pneumatic Impact Wrench** (hissing air leak, **needs repair**).  
- **Workbench with Calipers & Gauges** (strewn with copper shims).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Faded Propaganda Poster** ("*Complete the Decisive Battle Fleet!*").  
- **Rusted Coffee Tin** (repurposed as an ashtray).  
- **Dented Steel Toe Boots** (left near a puddle).  

---  

#### **MACHINE SHOP & ARMORY** *(Precision Assembly Zone)*  

**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Lathe & Milling Machines** (grease-stained, one with a **jammed feed screw**).  
- **Gun Barrel Polishing Rig** (rotating belts, fine brass dust everywhere).  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **100mm Dual-Purpose Gun Mount** – **missing traverse gears**, manual crank attached.  
- **Hydraulic Press** – **stuck in the down position**, requires bleeding.  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Tool Wall** (organized wrenches, but **two sockets missing**).  
- **Lubricant Dispenser** (dripping slightly, **needs refill**).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Chipped Imperial Navy Crest Mug** (holding pencils).  
- **Old Newspaper** (headline: *"U.S. Alaska-Class Threat Looms"*).  

---  

### **4. Scene Affordances and Embedded Potential**  

#### **Collaborative Transportation Affordances:**  
- **310mm Gun Turret (22 tons, 3m wide)** – Requires **two agents** to operate the gantry crane safely.  
- **Armor Plate (1.5 tons, awkward grip points)** – Needs **one agent to stabilize while another bolts it down**.  

#### **Reasoning and Tool-Use Affordances:**  
- **Attribute-Based Reasoning:** Among **five identical-looking rivet batches**, only **Batch #3** has the correct **copper-zinc alloy** (marked by a tiny red stripe).  
- **Compound Reasoning:**  
  - **Problem:** The **hydraulic press is jammed**.  
  - **Solution:** The **release valve key** is in the **Design Office desk drawer**.  

---  

This **densely interactive shipyard** is primed for **complex multi-agent tasks**—whether it’s **lifting a turret, fixing machinery, or decoding blueprints**, every object has **weight, purpose, and consequence**.
